data.title: Norman Ernest Borlaug (1914-2009)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for Norman Borlaug born 1914 Cresco, Howard, Iowa, United States died 2009 Dallas, Texas, United States including ancestors + 2 photos + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

[sibling(s) unknown]

[children unknown]

Problems/Questions

Profile last modified 28 Dec 2023 | Created 17 Dec 2018

This page has been accessed 985 times.

Biography

Norman Borlaug is Notable.

World Food Prize Foundation's biography Introduction by Ambassador Kenneth M. Quinn, PhD:

The Formative Years - From a one-room schoolhouse in Iowa to the University of Minnesota

In Touch with the Environment - Early work with the U.S. Forestry Service and discovering wheat rust

Confronting Poverty - Mexico - Joining CIMMYT^ and the early years of the Green Revolution

The Green Revolution from CIMMYT to South Asia - Saving millions of lives in the Muslim world

The Impact in Asia - The effect of the Green Revolution on peace and prosperity in Asia

The Nobel Prize - Prize-winning accomplishments and notable achievements

Bringing the Green Revolution to Africa - Spreading the Green Revolution through Sasakawa Africa

The World Food Prize - Creating a "Nobel Prize for Food and Agriculture"

Opening to China - The Green Revolution reaches China

Youth Education - Teaching lessons of food security to future generations

Conclusion - Applying Lessons to the 21st Century

^ CIMMYT - International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center

Norman was born in 1914. He passed away in 2009. Borlaug was the great-grandchild of Norwegian immigrants to the United States. Ole Olson Dybevig and Solveig Thomasdatter Rinde, of Feios, a small village in Vik kommune, Sogn og Fjordane, Norway, emigrated to Dane County, Wisconsin, in 1854. The family eventually moved to the small Norwegian-American community of Saude, near Cresco, Iowa. There they were members of Saude Lutheran Church, where Norman was both baptized and confirmed.

Borlaug was born to Henry Oliver (1889–1971) and Clara (Vaala) Borlaug (1888–1972) on his grandparents' farm in Saude in 1914, the first of four children. His three sisters were Palma Lillian (Behrens; 1916–2004), Charlotte (Culbert; b. 1919) and Helen (b. 1921). From age seven to nineteen, he worked on the 106-acre (43 ha) family farm west of Protivin, Iowa, fishing, hunting, and raising corn, oats, timothy-grass, cattle, pigs and chickens. He attended the one-teacher, one-room New Oregon #8 rural school in Howard County, through eighth grade.

Dr. Norman Borlaug was presented the Nobel Peace Prize in 1970 for his accomplishments in India and Pakistan and for his role as “Father of the Green Revolution.”

Sources

The Britannica Guide to The 100 Most Influential Scientists (2007), p. 296.
